name is Ryan Maliki I'm a Solutions Architect here with Amazon part of my role is to work with

with data so want to take a step back and think a little bit about what doing bi
and working on data related projects in the cloud is really about starts first
by thinking about the data that you're processing there's an increasing variety of data an increasing volume of data
that customers are dealing with this can range from traditional data sources flat
files that come out of legacy systems database ETL processes up through more
modern higher volume higher velocity datasets things like application logs that can be generated at the scale of
gigs per day through things like IOT sensor data where you might be dealing
with hundreds of gigs or terabytes per day the first step we really encourage
customers to think about when you're designing a data system is is landing
all that raw data the police that customers usually choose is s 3 s 3 is
our highly durable a highly available object store it's one of our first services and one of our most highly used
once you get your data into s3 you don't have to worry about am I going to lose
it is it is it going to be deleted you can go on to an analysis phase this
analysis phase can can take a number of different forms commonly we'll see
customers have some sort of a transport stop so reading that data off of s3 and
using a tool like Apache spark or hive to transform it into a cleaner or
optimized form on AWS you can run those
tools in EMR elastic MapReduce our distribution of Hadoop or we see
customers increasingly looking at tools like AWS glue which is a fully managed
SPARC execution environment where you can focus on the business logic you're implementing not the care and feeding of
a Hadoop cluster from there you might write your data back into s3 to be used by other tools
or you might ETL it into some data warehousing solution there's lots of
different choices Amazon's philosophy around data warehousing and and
databases in general is to really have purpose-built solutions tools that that
target the specific problems that you're dealing with rather than coming out with a one-size-fits-all it's going to do
your data warehousing and make you coffee type solution so one of the most
common data warehouse tools that customers choose is Amazon redshift this
is our massively scarole massively scalable of parallel processing data
warehouse it's it's a fork of Postgres but designed to run natively in
the cloud it can go from tens of gigs of data up through petabytes so in addition to redshift we see
customers often moving their data into more traditional relational database so
RDS is our manage database offering or even leveraging no sequel databases the
difference here a data warehouse redshift is more appropriate when you have a large amount of
granular data that you want to be processing but more optimized for a relatively
small number of users concurrently whereas something like a relational database is going to be good for already
aggregated that you have a large number of concurrent users accessing your data
warehouse or you could opt for something that's more cloud native
increasingly customers are adopting Amazon Athena Athena is a fully managed
version of Apache presto where you're able to query your data that's sitting
on s3 with Athena you send us a sequel query and we manage provisioning the
infrastructure executing your query returning the results to you and so you
don't have to do any of the maintenance of infrastructure instead you you just

they also include guides that go into a lot of detail on how to run these
solutions so one style of deployment is a standalone single instance deployment
you you'd install tableau server on ec2 instance and have it running in your V
PC you can make it publicly accessible over the internet or you might choose to make it only accessible within your your
organization's network generally encourage you to think carefully about how you're
allowing access to your tableau server generally you don't want all of your
data sitting there on the internet so being mindful of security you should treat your bi server
the same way you treat a database so that's the single node deployment the
other option is a clustered deployment here you're going to have a primary and
one or more worker nodes that are going to be spread across multiple availability zones so in AWS an
availability zone is a logical data center so one or more physical buildings and our region's can are composed of
multiple availability zones this gives you you high availability so that if
something were to happen in a single availability zone your application is spread out so you you don't have to
worry as much about availability the the other component in addition to having multiple servers running in a clustered
deployment of the tableau is how your traffic how your users are going to access those multiple servers this is
done through a load balancer leveraging AWS elastic load balancer so
one of the most common questions I encounter when I'm dealing with customers setting up a bi deployment is
what size should I pick how how big a server do I need how much CPU how much
memory and my best advice there is don't worry about it too much you with the
cloud you're able to adjust as you go you can you can scale up if you realize
you have more demand and conversely you can scale down I have customers who do
this over the course of of the year that they have a busy season so they scale up
and then when that busy season is done they scale down to run in the most cost-efficient manner there's to scaling
strategies the first is of vertical scaling so this means just moving to a
larger server on AWS if you're leveraging elastic
block storage for your instances scaling up is just a matter of stopping the
instance and swapping out the size so from the perspective of your application
it looks like you just rebooted something in this in the strategy your application would be offline for a
couple of minutes but this this is a really great way for applications that
don't have high availability needs which a lot of times if you ask yourself do
